articles.headline: Barclays Suit Sheds Light on Trading in Shadows
articles.snippet: Barclays’ dark pool seems to have catered to high-frequency traders, the very participants it claimed to protect against, a lawsuit contends.
articles.abstract: Barclays’ dark pool seems to have catered to high-frequency traders, the very participants it claimed to protect against, a lawsuit contends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dark pools just got a little brighter.

articles.headline: Paying Employees to Stay, Not to Go
articles.snippet: Restaurants like Shake Shack and Boloco that offer their employees above-average pay say they have lower turnover and better customer service.
articles.abstract: Restaurants like Shake Shack and Boloco that offer their employees above-average pay say they have lower turnover and better customer service.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — Ben Nawn, a sophomore at the University of New Hampshire, says his friends who work at McDonald’s are envious of what he earns working for the Boloco burrito restaurant here.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Aims of Donor Are Shadowed by Past in Coal
articles.snippet: Though the environmentalist Tom Steyer has vowed to sell his investments in companies that generate fossil fuels, the projects his hedge fund bankrolled may emit carbon for decades to come.
articles.abstract: Though the environmentalist Tom Steyer has vowed to sell his investments in companies that generate fossil fuels, the projects his hedge fund bankrolled may emit carbon for decades to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: To environmentalists across Australia, it is a baffling anachronism in an era of climate change: the construction of a 4,000-acre mine in New South Wales that will churn out carbon-laden coal for the next 30 years.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Virus Plagues the Pork Industry, and Environmentalists
articles.snippet: A disease is killing huge numbers of piglets and young hogs, and environmental groups worry about the buried carcasses’ effects on groundwater.
articles.abstract: A disease is killing huge numbers of piglets and young hogs, and environmental groups worry about the buried carcasses’ effects on groundwater.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bodies are piling up fast.

articles.headline: Now on Your Cellphone Bill, Services You Never Wanted
articles.snippet: Regulators say unauthorized charges, long a bane of landline accounts, have become a growing nuisance for mobile users as well.
articles.abstract: Regulators say unauthorized charges, long a bane of landline accounts, have become a growing nuisance for mobile users as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, phone carriers have wanted to find ways to make it easy for mobile customers to buy things and charge them to their phone bills.

articles.headline: Brazil Takes a Painful Step Forward
articles.snippet: Brazil dispatched an upstart Colombia team, 2-1, but lost its star player for the rest of the tournament.
articles.abstract: Brazil dispatched an upstart Colombia team, 2-1, but lost its star player for the rest of the tournament.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORTALEZA, Brazil — It was an enormous win for Brazil, but it came at a gigantic cost.

articles.headline: Californians Keep Up With Joneses’ Water Use
articles.snippet: In the five months since a drought emergency was declared, Californians have barely cut their water consumption, leading some residents to get personal about waste.
articles.abstract: In the five months since a drought emergency was declared, Californians have barely cut their water consumption, leading some residents to get personal about waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For all the doomsday proclamations about the historic drought that has this state in a chokehold, here is what Californians have done to save water: not much.

articles.headline: As They Invade, Argentines Seek Soccer Conquest
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of Argentines have traveled to Brazil, stirring worries among Brazilians about violence and about Argentina winning the World Cup.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of Argentines have traveled to Brazil, stirring worries among Brazilians about violence and about Argentina winning the World Cup.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — There is a new song going around the World Cup, a ditty sung by the Argentines to taunt their Brazilian hosts and longstanding rivals. The gist is simple. It asks the Brazilians how they feel about being bossed around in their own country and tells them to prepare for an Argentine championship on their own soil.

articles.headline: Refugee Camp for Syrians in Jordan Evolves as a Do-It-Yourself City
articles.snippet: As the sprawling Zaatari camp evolves into an informal city — with an economy and even gentrification — aid workers say camps can be potential urban incubators that benefit host countries like Jordan.
articles.abstract: As the sprawling Zaatari camp evolves into an informal city — with an economy and even gentrification — aid workers say camps can be potential urban incubators that benefit host countries like Jordan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — A young Syrian salesman stopped into Ahmad Bidawi’s barbershop for a shave the other day. Music wafted on fan-cooled air. Outside, on what has become the main commercial strip here in one of the world’s largest refugee camps, workers steered handcarts packed with lumber and kitchen appliances through sunbaked crowds hanging out in front of shops.

articles.headline: Obama Weighs Steps to Cover Contraception
articles.snippet: The Obama administration, reeling from decisions by the Supreme Court, is weighing options to provide contraceptive coverage to women who are about to lose it or never had it because of their employers’ religious objections.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration, reeling from decisions by the Supreme Court, is weighing options to provide contraceptive coverage to women who are about to lose it or never had it because of their employers’ religious objections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, reeling from back-to-back blows from the Supreme Court this week, is weighing options that would provide contraceptive coverage to thousands of women who are about to lose it or never had it because of their employers’ religious objections.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: When Taxes and Profits Are Oceans Apart
articles.snippet: Many American companies won’t divulge the tax bills they would face by bringing home their overseas earnings. It’s a figure that investors could benefit from knowing.
articles.abstract: Many American companies won’t divulge the tax bills they would face by bringing home their overseas earnings. It’s a figure that investors could benefit from knowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s a question for investors in any big United States corporation with foreign operations: Do you know what the company’s tax bill would be if it had to bring its overseas earnings home?

articles.headline: Pro-Russian Fighters Routed From Stronghold, Ukraine Says
articles.snippet: The Ukrainian government said Saturday that it had pushed pro-Russian fighters out of Slovyansk, a long-blockaded rebel stronghold where some of the fiercest fighting has occurred during the more than three-month separatist insurrection.
articles.abstract: The Ukrainian government said Saturday that it had pushed pro-Russian fighters out of Slovyansk, a long-blockaded rebel stronghold where some of the fiercest fighting has occurred during the more than three-month separatist insurrection.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — With a fierce onslaught of gunfire and mortar shelling, Ukrainian government forces on Saturday expelled pro-Russian insurgents from Slovyansk, a long-blockaded rebel stronghold, government officials and separatist leaders said.

articles.headline: For Bellicose Brazil, Payback Carries Heavy Price: Loss of Neymar
articles.snippet: The referee’s failure to control Friday’s game between Brazil and Colombia contributed to an ugly atmosphere and a World Cup-ending injury to Brazil’s star striker.
articles.abstract: The referee’s failure to control Friday’s game between Brazil and Colombia contributed to an ugly atmosphere and a World Cup-ending injury to Brazil’s star striker.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Colombian defender named Juan Camilo Zúñiga ended the World Cup for the Brazilian star striker Neymar on Friday with a nasty knee into Neymar’s back that fractured one of his vertebrae. It was an ugly play and a bad foul. It deserved, at least, a yellow card.

articles.headline: A Mad Scramble for Young Bankers
articles.snippet: Private-equity firms are pushing earlier than ever to lure Wall Street investment banks’ most promising talent.
articles.abstract: Private-equity firms are pushing earlier than ever to lure Wall Street investment banks’ most promising talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: A battle is raging on Wall Street as never before, with powerful factions scrambling for control of a precious resource.

articles.headline: At Zingerman’s, Pastrami and Partnership to Go
articles.snippet: From its beginnings in Ann Arbor, Mich., a deli has grown into a circle of businesses, all celebrating employee involvement.
articles.abstract: From its beginnings in Ann Arbor, Mich., a deli has grown into a circle of businesses, all celebrating employee involvement.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a typical Wednesday morning at Zingerman’s Roadhouse, a restaurant in Ann Arbor, Mich., that offers nine varieties of macaroni and cheese and smokes its own hogs for pulled pork. But on this particular morning, in a colorful back dining room, finance was on the menu.

articles.headline: Free Video Games Say Pay Up or Wait, Testing Players’ Patience
articles.snippet: Free-to-download mobile games have become a lucrative business, but aggressive appeals for in-app purchases are turning off some players.
articles.abstract: Free-to-download mobile games have become a lucrative business, but aggressive appeals for in-app purchases are turning off some players.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of gaming, as in life, you get what you pay for.

articles.headline: The Amazon’s Floating Fields
articles.snippet: Inhabitants of a floating village in the Amazon River basin have adapted their lives, and their passion for playing soccer, to the annual flooding of the Black River.
articles.abstract: Inhabitants of a floating village in the Amazon River basin have adapted their lives, and their passion for playing soccer, to the annual flooding of the Black River.
articles.lead_paragraph: CATALÃO, Brazil — In this floating village, there is only one way to travel. Students go to school by boat. Pentecostals go to church by boat. Taxis arrive by boat. Even the soccer field is often a boat.

articles.headline: Coming to U.S. for Baby, and Womb to Carry It
articles.snippet: Foreign citizens now make up most of the clients at large surrogacy agencies in the United States, highlighting a divide between the country and much of the world over fundamental questions on family.
articles.abstract: Foreign citizens now make up most of the clients at large surrogacy agencies in the United States, highlighting a divide between the country and much of the world over fundamental questions on family.
articles.lead_paragraph: At home in Lisbon, a gay couple invited friends over to a birthday celebration, and at the end of the evening shared a surprise — an ultrasound image of their baby, moving around in the belly of a woman in Pennsylvania being paid to carry their child.

articles.headline: Power Struggles in Middle East Exploit Islam’s Ancient Sectarian Rift
articles.snippet: Bahrain, the first place where Arab Spring protests degenerated into Sunni-Shiite feuds, now appears to have been a signal of what was to come in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Bahrain, the first place where Arab Spring protests degenerated into Sunni-Shiite feuds, now appears to have been a signal of what was to come in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIFFA, Bahrain — Black and yellow concrete barricades block the roads entering this wealthy Sunni enclave, where foreign-born Sunni soldiers in armored personnel carriers guard the mansions of the ruling family and the business elite.

articles.headline: Students Joining Battle to Upend Laws on Voter ID
articles.snippet: College students have joined a legal challenge in North Carolina, claiming that the state’s requirements discriminate based on age.
articles.abstract: College students have joined a legal challenge in North Carolina, claiming that the state’s requirements discriminate based on age.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Civil rights groups have spent a decade fighting requirements that voters show photo identification, arguing that this discriminates against African-Americans, Hispanics and the poor. This week in a North Carolina courtroom, another group will make its case that such laws are discriminatory: college students.

articles.headline: 6 Israelis Held Over the Killing of Palestinian
articles.snippet: A group of Israelis was arrested in what one official described as a revenge killing. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pledged to pursue the case and said, “We do not differentiate between terrorists.”
articles.abstract: A group of Israelis was arrested in what one official described as a revenge killing. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pledged to pursue the case and said, “We do not differentiate between terrorists.”
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Confronting the possibility of rising retaliatory violence between Jews and Palestinians, the Israeli authorities arrested six Israelis on Sunday in the killing of a Palestinian teenager, found beaten and burned in a Jerusalem forest last week.

articles.headline: Reno Rolls the Dice on High-Tech
articles.snippet: The Nevada city is looking to shed its casino-town image and become a hub of e-commerce ventures, an Apple data center and a drone testing ground.
articles.abstract: The Nevada city is looking to shed its casino-town image and become a hub of e-commerce ventures, an Apple data center and a drone testing ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — A street newly nicknamed Startup Row intersects this city’s old strip of casinos touting Money Maker Jackpots and Crazy Cash Slot Tournaments.

articles.headline: Participant Index Seeks to Determine Why One Film Spurs Activism, While Others Falter
articles.snippet: A film company, two foundations and a university want to know what motivates people to support an issue on social media after they see issue-oriented movies, TV shows or online video.
articles.abstract: A film company, two foundations and a university want to know what motivates people to support an issue on social media after they see issue-oriented movies, TV shows or online video.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — You watched the wrenching documentary. You posted your outrage on Twitter. But are you good for more than a few easy keystrokes of hashtag activism?

articles.headline: Brazil’s Other Beautiful Games
articles.snippet: In the Amazon rain forest, there is a tournament that is equal parts soccer and beauty pageant, played by hundreds of amateur teams which enter their own beauty queens.
articles.abstract: In the Amazon rain forest, there is a tournament that is equal parts soccer and beauty pageant, played by hundreds of amateur teams which enter their own beauty queens.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — It was a newsroom like any television station newsroom, unless you count the brunette receptionist wearing a crown, sash and leopard print dress and offering friendly advice on how to spice up the World Cup.

articles.headline: G.M. OnStar Data Has Potential as Safety Tool
articles.snippet: General Motors’ OnStar system provides streams of data about the performance of G.M. vehicles, but the automaker says little about how it uses this information to investigate problems.
articles.abstract: General Motors’ OnStar system provides streams of data about the performance of G.M. vehicles, but the automaker says little about how it uses this information to investigate problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: As General Motors overhauls its approach to safety, one powerful tool may be a technology that dates back two decades — the OnStar in-car assistance system.

articles.headline: Principles Are No Match for Europe’s Love of U.S. Web Titans
articles.snippet: European consumers may criticize Facebook’s privacy policies or working conditions at Amazon, but they are still hooked on American technology companies.
articles.abstract: European consumers may criticize Facebook’s privacy policies or working conditions at Amazon, but they are still hooked on American technology companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On weekends, Guillaume Rosquin browses the shelves of local bookstores in Lyon, France. He enjoys peppering the staff with questions about what he should be reading next. But his visits, he says, are also a protest against the growing power of Amazon. He is bothered by the way the American online retailer treats its warehouse employees.

articles.headline: Ukraine Military Finds Its Footing Against Pro-Russian Rebels
articles.snippet: Since President Petro O. Poroshenko called off a cease-fire and ordered troops to end the rebellion, an entirely different Ukrainian military appeared at the front.
articles.abstract: Since President Petro O. Poroshenko called off a cease-fire and ordered troops to end the rebellion, an entirely different Ukrainian military appeared at the front.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — When pro-Russian rebels first fanned out across eastern Ukraine in April, seizing public buildings, ousting local officials and blockading streets and highways, the government’s security forces — a ragtag lot of poorly equipped and understaffed military and police units — were largely paralyzed by dysfunction and defection. They seemed to remain so for months.

articles.headline: World Cup Players Are Using Hands More Than Ever (to Tweet)
articles.snippet: This year’s tournament is notable for a widespread use of social media by athletes eager to issue confessions, explanations and interpretations after controversial incidents.
articles.abstract: This year’s tournament is notable for a widespread use of social media by athletes eager to issue confessions, explanations and interpretations after controversial incidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Zinedine Zidane of France did not apologize on MySpace after his infamous head butt in the 2006 World Cup final. Diego Maradona of Argentina did not address his 1986 knuckle-assisted Hand of God goal on America Online, a digital community that did not become prominent for another five years.

articles.headline: Semifinals Remain an Inner Sanctum Until Further Notice
articles.snippet: In order to join the ranks of the World Cup elite, countries like the United States need to incubate soccer talent.
articles.abstract: In order to join the ranks of the World Cup elite, countries like the United States need to incubate soccer talent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The World Cup, ultimately, is a highly exclusive club.

articles.headline: Immigrants From Latin America and Africa Squeezed as Banks Curtail International Money Transfers
articles.snippet: Under regulatory pressure, many banks are ending or limiting money transfers, most likely meaning higher costs for immigrants sending money home.
articles.abstract: Under regulatory pressure, many banks are ending or limiting money transfers, most likely meaning higher costs for immigrants sending money home.
articles.lead_paragraph: As government regulators crack down on the financing of terrorists and drug traffickers, many big banks are abandoning the business of transferring money from the United States to other countries, moves that are expected to reverse years of declines in the cost of immigrants sending money home to their families.

articles.headline: Testing Ground for a New Detroit
articles.snippet: The North End, which has both glorious homes and some of the city’s harshest blight, captures both the hope and challenge of the mayor’s pledge to improve Detroit.
articles.abstract: The North End, which has both glorious homes and some of the city’s harshest blight, captures both the hope and challenge of the mayor’s pledge to improve Detroit.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Inell Byrd’s house has a leaky roof.
